description: From wrig +‎ -le (frequentative suffix). Compare Dutch wriggelen (“to wriggle, squirm”), Low German wriggeln (“to wriggle”). Related to Old English wrigian (“to turn, wend, hie, go move”), from Proto-Germanic *wrigōną (“to wriggle”).

verbs.description: wriggle (third-person singular simple present wriggles, present participle wriggling, simple past and past participle wriggled)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To twist one's body to and fro with short, writhing motions; to squirm.
examples: Teachers often lose their patience when children wriggle in their seats.
He was sitting on the lawn, wriggling his toes in the grass.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To use crooked or devious means.
